text: It took six hours to set upI am a techy electronics engineer.  I have dozens of patents in electronics and have written thousands of lines of computer code, in three different programming languages.  But this watch is quite a challenge.When I tried to pair the watch to the phone, the phone said I must update the phone to OS 14.8.1.  Yet I have always had "automatic updates" "on" in the phone menu.So I spent a half-hour updating to OS 14.8.1.I tried to pair the watch to the phone again and the phone said my OS must be updated.  But I had just updated it.  So I called apple support.  They directed me to update my OS to 15.1.  Why was I previously directed to update to 14.8.1 when that was obsolete?  Updating to 15.1 took an hour!Next when I tried to pair the watch, the message on the phone says that I need to charge the watch.  I examined the watch charge cable and it must plug into a USB "C" charger which is not included with the watch.  Do you have such a charger?  I didn't even know such chargers existed.  I have ten chargers, including several made by apple, and they all only accept the original USB plug, called USB "A".I recall reading a few weeks ago that apple was no longer including chargers.  I thought, that's ok, we all have lots of chargers.  But nobody has USB "C" chargers, they are very new.So I ordered a USB "C" charger.The charger arrived I started the pairing process.  But the phone stuck for 30 minutes during the pairing process so I called support.  They couldn't get it to work by the standard way, which is to update the watch software, so they opted to install without updating the watch software.  That worked with lots of hand holding and took about 45 minutesAll together I spent about six hours getting the phone to work.Has apple lost their mind?
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2021
title: It took six hours to set up
Color: (PRODUCT)RED Aluminum Case w (PRODUCT)RED Band

text: Looking thru all the reviews and most of the negative ones are about battery life not satisfactory. I have tested my Apple Watch series 7 with not having the “always on” display and found that if I turn that setting off I only burn 25-30% battery in a full work day 10 hrs. I don’t know about you but if I’m not looking at my watch, why would I need the display on? When you turn “always on” display feature off watch display comes on only when you look at it immediately and that’s perfect for me. Just go to display and brightness on your phone in the Apple Watch app and turn off “always on” . Think about if your phone had a setting where it was always on……it would be dead in no time and everyone would be complaining the battery doesn’t last.

text: Apple does a lot of stuff well.  Mac Books, iMac, iPad, and iPhone.  As a fitness tracker it is excellent and how it integrates so well with the iPhone, but as a watch is another matter altogether.  The short battery life, the rectangular watch face limiting details, and no seconds indication when in low-power-always-on-display mode are all big drawbacks.The Apple Watch will get you at around 26 hours on a full charge. This is completely unacceptable if you are frequent traveler or someone who falls asleep with their watch on.  It is one more thing to charge in such a short time.  Your phone you put down after some time, but a watch is used more frequently.Sometimes in 2022 or by 2024, Apple should introduce an Apple Watch which has greater than 36 hours in a round face. text: Initially, I never wanted a Smart Watch. Then, my husband got one & I thought his was pretty cool. SO I started looking at one similar to what he had (a Fossil), but was unable to find something I liked, or could even tolerate. Since I have (and love) my iPhone, I decided to look into the Apple watched, and found this one on Amazon. Although the price was rather off-putting, my husband & I decided that, with all of the health benefits the watch has, I should go ahead & order it. Well, since getting the watch. I've worn it all day, every day, and I simply think the watch is AMAZING! I can check my heart rate throughout the day (something I need to do), and keep an eye on my blood sugar levels (since I am a Type One Diabetic, and have the DexCom App on my iPhone, it also shows on my watch--how cool!). The watch encourages me to stand up a couple of times an hour, which is great, since I work from home & sit at a computer for eight hours/day. I love that I can make/receive phone calls from the watch, too. In the week that I've had my watch, I've found that I use my watch more than I use my iPhone. And to think that I was so.very.opposed to getting a Smart Watch... Now, I don't know how I ever got by without it.

text: This is about my 7th smart "watch". I've have a couple of Fitbits, a Jawbone, a Zenwatch 3 (prettiest of the bunch), a Samsung Galaxy, and an Amazfit Bip (good watch for the money). I've basically got a smart watch museum. I got the Apple Watch because, honestly, I'm getting older and I wanted the fall detection and health features. I've had it for a couple of weeks and here's what I think, from bad to good.1. Battery life sucks. It'll get through one day, but that's it. The Bip would last for 3 weeks on a charge.2. The screen isn't great in direct sun. It's better than some others, but doesn't hold a candle to the Bip, which was somehow reflective in bright light, sort of like a Kindle.3. The sleep tracking is ok, about what you'd expect from a movement detecter, but the app for it isn't very good. Stick with one of the gadgets that goes under your mattress for now.4. It has some very nice watch faces, with custom complications. Best of the bunch.5. Very comfortable to wear. The big stem doesn't get in the way at all.6. The health features work great. It accurately tracks you pulse, and will check you blood oxygen and ECG on demand. I wish it would do the blood oxygen periodically with low saturation detection, but battery is likely a problem.7. The fitness features rock. Even without a subscription, the watch has helped me get my exercise.It has a ton of other useful features. Siri works fine, you can control Spotify with it, maps are kind of fun. Lots of other things. The really good thing is that, as the practical king of smart watches, there are 3rd party apps/integrations to do just about anything that could make sense, and it's unlikely the watch will be orphaned like my AndroidWear watches were.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2022
title: Truly excellent smart watch, if you need one of them.

text: I’ve always been a smart watch user, however, being that I recently converted to Apple after finding that I enjoy their products and software, I needed a new watch.This product is beautiful. The screen is high resolution, it’s fast, and you can seamlessly transfer between phone and watch. The screen is small, but it displays a lot more information at once than I really expected it to, so using it isn’t a headache.I love the utility. Everything you think a smart watch should do, this watch CAN do. From needing a calculator, to switching your songs, tracking your activity & workouts- basing the calories burned on your heart rate. I exercise a lot and appreciate the information smart watches can bring. You can text, call, read emails, make payments. Etc.The only issue I have with the watch is an issue I have with apple products in general- if you’re like me and this is your first apple watch- you’re probably going to have to watch a tutorial or two in order to know how to turn it on, and to know what this watch can really do for you. Apple does offer “helpful tips” but those tips aren’t really comprehensive as to how to use your watch. I probably still don’t know all I can do with it, which is cool, but frustrating.

text: After 7 iterations, I finally got my first Apple Watch. The reason why I held up so long was because of a simple question: WHY DO I NEED AN APPLE WATCH?For the most part, I am pretty simplistic and live by minimal means. The reason I FINALLY got an Apple Watch was because I wanted something truly waterproof, durable, and has great utility. The AP7 does it all. I'm also getting older, and I want to keep track of my health. I want to have access to as many metrics to analyze my health.The AP7 helps keep me focusing on the bigger picture. I'm able to handle my notifications without having the need to lift my phone which does, in some form, interrupt my productivity. The next biggest reason why I am happy with this particular variant is because of sleep tracking. To maximize my day-to-day productivity, I need the best quality of sleep. So apps like SleepWatch are a great tool to use to track sleep.It is really easy to connect to my iPhone 13 Pro, and the whole setup process took about 15 minutes including updates.However, my biggest drawback for the AP7 is its battery life. It doesn't bother me so much, but I have to charge it every night.It looks amazing, has professional and luxury vibes, and is pretty customizable. There are non-OEM bands on here that are relatively inexpensive and affordable especially for those on a budget to personalize the AP7 to their liking.Overall, I am pretty happy with it! Cheers.

text: After spending $800 for this thing, I had to spend another $20 to get a USB-C charger cube. I must have 20 USB-A cubes, but this is not compatible. Of all the zillion devices I have, none need a USB-C female charging outlet. I understand why USB-C is needed, but not to include a charger cube?With the battery arriving DOA, I had to charge it from my laptop which was not very convenient since my laptop USB-C port is used for several other purposes.They must have saved $2. Oh ... add it right to the bottom line.There are also no instructions included whatsoever.What a bad first impression.Setup took over two hours with required updates, downloads, authorizations, pairings, log-ins, etc. I suppose a lengthy setup is understandable ... but did I mention no charger and no instructions? I'm not likely to get over that. Really ... how cheap can you get Apple?It is interesting to note that I got a 31 page printed manual along with my Apple branded USB-C charger cube I had to order, but absolutely nothing along with my watch!!How cheap can you get Apple? How cheap can you get?It's an amazing device, but products that don't present themselves well when opening the box are doomed to failure in the market. I am both upset with and shocked at Apple for this.3 stars is all you get. All the incredible engineering that went into this was lost on me immediately by the decisions made by some idiot product/marketing manager.I am soooo done with Apple products.

text: It's far more beautiful in person than shown here. I bought a $15 black chain and it's beautiful: perfect for me. I've always been fascinated by watches but never owned one I enjoyed so much. Also, my watch tells me, accurately, my Oxygen level. Some folks have claimed it's inaccurate, but it's correct the way I use it, which I will explain here. Please note: I've compared it to my oximeter which is absolutely accurate compared to one of the world's largest hospitals oxygen reporting machines, and it's inline with both.At sleep my oxygen goes down, so it's accuracy is imperative to me. I wear it on my left wrist slightly further away from my hands. I use my hands a lot playing guitar, doing dishes, typing.The ECC is fascinating, but I'm blessed to not have need of it, at this point.I like the awards and motivational achievement things.I love how it finds my phone, my daughter's phone and wife's phone.The display is fantastic. Beautiful. The faces are wonderful.The price dropped dramatically and I nearly sent it back. I didn't because I love the watch. The original band it came with really is awful.I love the way it charges with a magnetic no plug charger. It charges very fast. I have to charge it once a day.The speaker and mic are okay. They work, although I feel funny talking into my watch. Futuristic in a retro way.The band it comes with did not work for me at all. It has two sizes, but it appears flimsy and keeps falling off. On the plus side it fell many times, and I nearly returned it for that, but it did not break, so I did not. Watch bands are plentiful and all are better than the OEM.Does not take blood pressure, as far as I can tell. That's about all it doesn't do.I'm not yet certain about subscribing to the apple watch thing. I have a 3 month trial period before I will decide. So far I haven't needed that aspect of it. I suppose if I were to work out on my own it would be very good.Great watch -- beautiful, appears to be water proof. Strong. Great display. So long as it lasts I'm very happy. Replace the OEM band immediately. It's been my experience that my Apple products last a long time.My daughter and wife both want one.

text: This is only day 2 of my apple smart watch. So far the capacity of the series 7 far out weighs the fitbit versa 2 accept it doesn't seem to collect as much sleep data as the fitbit did. As usual the setup was pretty intuitive. Remember if you are looking for data collected to look in the Apple Health App that comes with your iphone. I love tekky stuff so this watch will keep me busy for a while. I paid almost 3 times as much for the Apple watch as I did my versa 2 so I am expecting a lot more. I may adjust the star ratings as I become more aquanted with the watch. I was a little disappointed in the charging cable not including the power adaptor. It has a magnetic end that attaches to the watch, which is nice because if you use a screen protector you won't have to  remove it to charge the watch. The other end however is a type-C and I had  no power adaptors with a type-C. I was able to  charge it with my tablet and I also have a couple of portable power supplies that have type-C so I am good until my new power adaptor arrives. I was reading in a forum and another person complained about the same thing and someone pointed out that it is our responsibilty to find out what's in the box. That's true but for that price I still think you should get one with the watch. Apple claims it's to help the enviornment. text: After years of using Pebble and Amazfit watches I decided to go Apple Watch because of the heart monitoring features and solid support for my iOS devices (phone, tablet). The watch works great. Getting it setup with my iPhone 12 Pro was just a non-event. It worked instantly.The display is amazing. Just gorgeous. The reaction time with using the screen, crown, or button is instant. No lag at all.The only issue I have is the battery. I never went to Apple Watch before Series 7 because 24 or less hours of battery life and having to carry a custom charging base everywhere I got is just untenable.Series 7 docs state even with always on display the average is a goal of 18 hours. HA. I'm lucky to get 10 or 12 and it doesn't even do much during the day. I've tested others like several Android watches over the years too and none were this consumptive of battery.The sleep tracking works fine, but it's not comfortable to wear in bed all night. I don't think any "band" is.Overall, I like it. I'll use it. It works super well with my iPhone and the apps are great. But honestly, if I had known the battery life was this short with average usage, I would have probably gone with another Amazfit or the Pebble based FitBit Versa 3.

text: First, I am a long time user of Mac products but this is my first Apple Watch so I cannot offer comparisons to previous versions. As I am both active and getting older, the emergency fall function seemed practical. It is but, in terms of health monitoring, it offers much more. From ECGs and other heart parameters  to sleep records, fitness records and more, it gives one a definitive record of activity/inactivity, momentum vs inertia. As the AW mirrors much of your iPhone, there is too much to describe.41 vs 45? That is a matter of personal choice. Readability is a frequent question. While I am male, 6 foot and 175lbs, I chose the 41 because it was available and I prefer a smaller piece on my wrist. The screen display is very customizable, it works for me (I attached a photo for reference). The standard sports band is fine but there are many alternatives available.The cellular function? It seemed essential in case I was out of range of my iPhone. After fielding many calls using the AW only, the quality is indistinguishable from my iPhone. Next step is figuring out wireless earbuds 😎. Not to mention little things like haptic alarms, subtle but effective. Battery life could be better but, with high use, it lasts a full day. I charge it when I awaken in the morning and haven’t dipped below 20%.Bottom line? I can’t believe I spent this much on this watch but I’m glad I did. Yes, there are alternative, less pricey choices, I looked at many. I am pleased with the AW7.

text: As a long-time Apple Watch user, I initially thought that the Series 7 was not worth upgrading to. After all, my trusty Series 4 had many of the same features (delivering notifications silently on my wrist, sleep tracking, heart rate monitoring, and an EKG party-trick ability that I rarely use but is cool to have I guess) and was more than adequate enough for my use case. However, my Series 4's battery life was waning, and I was itching to move on from a rose gold watch, so when I saw that the price of this particular Series 7 variation dropped to $379, I knew I could afford to pull the trigger. Compared to my Series 4, this watch has many iterative improvements, including an always-on display, slightly larger screen, and a blood oxygen sensor, that when taken as a whole, make me a happy customer. The midnight color is definitely better-looking in person as well! If you're an existing Apple Watch user and have an older model, then this is an upgrade worth considering. If you're looking to get into the smartwatch world and have an iPhone, then this could be a good starter smartwatch for you.

text: There's no secret, as new smartwatches keep joining the battle, it's still Apple who keeps winning the race. Workout tracking, steps, heart rate, ECG, blood oxigen, unlocking your iPhone and Mac without Face ID or passcode, Apple Pay, notifications for all apps on your wrist, etc. It's a very cool gadget to have, very useful and very functional.To me, the only down side is still the battery. There are other smartwatches that beat the Apple Watch big time on battery, so it makes you wonder what does Apple need to create a watch with a battery that lasts as least a couple of days.Aside from the battery, which to me only represents the hastle of putting the watch on the charger for about an hour (The charging is super fast now), there's nothing else to complain about. I picked the aluminum red one with the standard silicone band and I absolutely love it.

text: Sleeker, better connected, more efficiently charged, faster, more intuitively organized and managed than ever before. The single greatest advance among my repertoire of uses is its connectivity with messaging—I just don't miss messages anymore; of course, I can put them off or ignore them whenever that's best but even that is more easily handled. And next is the music I can now store on it, which is easily accomplished and saves me taking my phone to the gym where I was forever misplacing it. And next is the improvement in ease and accuracy of the ECG recording of heart rhythm; I'm nearly 80, so knowing I am or am not in atrial fibrillation is important to me on occasion, which does not come up for me everyday, but when it does I want the watch to work, to do its thing; and now it does. I am grateful. I could go on (and on), but I won't. If you have need, and means, buy it.

text: Purchased the device for the purposes 1) to track sleep and 2) to avoid missing notifications when the phone is away.Good:- looks nice- charges fast (you go to shower, get back - fully charged, but you need to use only the original charger)- notifications are delivered effectively, with images- Apple Pay works- like other Apple products, has "find me" featureBad:- heavy, especially if you plan to sleep with it on- have to recharge every 24 hours;- sleep tracking is weak because you must pre-configure sleep time range (i.e. 9pm-6am) in the app; otherwise feature does not work; if you take a nap during the day, it will not be counted; if you have an unstable sleeping schedule and need to rely on the device with tracking your sleep - better use Fitbit- backward communication from the watch to iPhone, say, when you confirm a request in Authenticator app, works unstablySummary:A very stylish gadget with convenient one-way access to notifications and simple built-in functions. If lose it - and you may due to frequent recharge - you can always find it. If you have requirements similar to mine, consider a cheaper device. If you desire Apple Watch for the sake of having another Apple product, price is justified.

text: I have a series 4 and have never felt the need to upgrade, as my battery life still lasts me nearly two days. It hasn't been slowed down by any software updates, and still works fine. I finally decided to upgrade to the series 7 for the larger, always-on screen and blood oxygen sensor. It is definitely not worth it. I don't know if it's due to the always-on screen or what, but the battery life of this new series 7 is far worse than on my 3+ year-old series 4 watch. When I take the watch off, it only has ~35% battery left at the end of the day, and that is with barely any use (whereas my series 4 can still end the day with over 50% battery left). I imagine if I had any workouts or used many apps on the watch during the couple of weeks of owning the watch, it would have died before the end of the day. Also, the blood oxygen only seems to work about half the time, and the readings are all over the place. Again, I upgraded to have the always-on display, but that's pointless if I have to disable it to get decent battery life.

text: It took half a day to set up.  I had to leave it with my iPhone within range of WiFi and connected to chargers while I downloaded a long series of updates and performed a long series of restarts.The battery life is about 18 hours so I need to take it off to charge while I sleep.  This makes it difficult to use as a sleep monitor and use it as a watch all day.The watch isn’t very useful without being always linked to my iPhone.  Now I have to have  Bluetooth on my iPhone always on which sucks battery life. Also, the watch/iPhone combo made the decision for me that my iPhone alerts are now silent and the watch will tap my wrist for alerts.  After missing a couple appointments I had to disconnect the watch by turning off Bluetooth.  I searched through the hundreds of settings and couldn’t find the one where I gave permission to make decisions about iPhone settings without my consents.Apple doesn’t include power supplies anymore and they switched all there power cords to a new connector so I can’t use the 10 old power supplies I have sitting in a drawer.  Seems like a cash grab.  I guess they are out of ideas for new useful products that would increase sales.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2021
title: Not practical
Color: Green Aluminum Case with Clover Sport Band

date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
title: Fantastic watch. Very happy I upgraded from the series 4.
Color: Green Aluminum Case with Clover Sport Band

text: Okay, I've been an Android fan since, well, since the very beginning...I still am if I'm being honest. I have also spent a ridiculously large amount of $$ on smart watches over the years starting with the original Moto 360 (anyone remember that flat tire?). It LOOKED cool, especially that round face, but performance-wise, well, it was kinda terrible. The battery life was insultingly horrible (it would lose 7% in the ten minute drive to work while just sitting on my wrist doing nothing). But the potential was there. In finally switched to Samsung's Tizen at the introduction of the Gear S2. What a great watch that was. I went on to the Gear S3, the Gear Sport, the Galaxy Watch, the GW3 and then I heard the news: Samsung was going back to Wear OS. This disappointed me greatly. Over the years I have owned well over a dozen watches utilizing Wear OS (or Android Wear before that) and while I loved a lot about many of them, they ALL suffered from the stuttering and glitching that plagues essentially ALL Wear OS devices. Some have managed to work around that to produce the best version they possibly can (TicWatch Pro 3 and the Oppo Watch are just 2 examples) but each had at least something that just didn't work properly - and I don't blame either manufacturer for this. It's an ongoing problem with Wear OS itself. Slowly, I began to warm to the idea that maybe, just MAYBE Samsung will make it work the way it was always supposed to work. So, I bought the Galaxy Watch 4.Did Samsung fix Wear OS? In a word: NO. It still suffers from glitches, hiccups and stuttering and apps not opening properly and/or timely. At times it works just great (which is more often than not, but still...), I have a fairly expensive watch that ruins what otherwise ought to be a smoother experience than what I'm getting. My Galaxy Watch 3 runs fantastic (it runs on TIzen software and not Wear OS) and honestly, I have had zero issues with it since I got it over a year ago, nor any with my previous Tizen watches including the Gear S2, S3, Gear Sport and original Galaxy Watch. I have had intermittent issues with the GW4 since the day I brought it home. To be fair, I have heard many people who claim that their Watch 4's have run flawlessly since they bought theirs...but I cannot speak to their experience, only the one I've had - but I brought it up to be fair.I have done a LOT of research regarding all different kinds of smart watches, and you know what you almost never hear from the majority of apple watch owners? You don't hear about not getting a notification, or stuttering and glitches here and there. Sure, I'm sure they exist, but the overwhelming majority generally say the same thing: the watch JUST WORKS. Honestly, that is all I really care about. Does it do what it claims and does it do it consistently? From an Android Fanboy, I can say this without reservation: the apple watch works and does so CONSISTENTLY. I simply cannot say that about my GW4 or any other Wear OS device I have used over the last 6-8 years.Okay, now why did I switch? Well, when I heard that the apple watch could be used without an iPhone, it really caught my attention. Seriously, an apple watch that can be set up so the user does not need an iPhone?? Well that's just what I wanted to hear. The truth is, once the watch is set up with "Family Setup" as long as it's an LTE model watch, you do not need to have it paired with an iPhone AT ALL...however (and this is a biggie) - you STILL need an iPhone to set it up initially. That sucked. But - I have enough friends with iPhone's that I took the plunge anyway.The watch looks phenomenal BTW. I got the blue model and that new watch face that takes advantage of the larger screen is fantastic. Since this is my very first apple watch, I can't speak to how well it compares to earlier models, so I'm sorry about that. Honestly however, having not used a previous model before, I just don't see that there is a difference that is noticeable when compared to my friends who have earlier model apple watches. The major thing I like is exactly what I wanted most: a watch that is reliable. It took a bit of getting used to because I have been so familiar with Wear OS and Tizen watches for so long, but it isn't difficult, just takes a little time, that's all. I haven't always liked the apple rectangular shape...but slowly, it grew on me. It was always made really well, of that there has never been any doubt, but the series 7 is just great to look at.The one thing keeping my review from 5 to only 4 stars was the pretty HUGE omission of the charging block. As you've no doubt gathered by now, I'm a android guy and always have been. My last 4 phones have all used USB-C chargers...but none of them came with blocks that the USB-C cord went into, they all had the USB-C port on only ONE end, not both. It's fair to assume the majority of apple users do not own one of these, either. Meaning, it's an unnecessary EXTRA expense you absolutely MUST make in order to even be able to use your watch - unless you have a charger from a previous apple watch which you can still use, but you won't be able to take advantage of the faster charging time. For what apple is charging for this watch, leaving this out is nothing shy of a ginormous cash grab on their part, and it's rather blatant and disappointing. Seriously guys, this is simple greed...and if anyone at their HQ bothers to read any of these reviews will note that there are quite a few upset genuine apple fanatics who really are quite upset by this same situation, so I am definitely NOT alone here. Wise up apple or you'll force longtime fans into the arms of Wear OS simply to make a statement.With that said, the watch operates extraordinarily well. I have seen zero hiccups that I see each time I turned on my Galaxy Watch 4 (seriously, EVERY time I turn it on, I get a notification that tells me I have voice mail, but when I check, there is nothing there - literally EVERY SINGLE TIME I turn the watch on. After 3 months...it got old...and now it simply makes me mad). I've always heard of the great haptics on apple devices and now I know what they mean. Samsung does a pretty good job as well on their watches, don't get me wrong, but these are just, well, better. It's hard to describe unless you've actually worn one to feel the difference. My TicWatch Pro 3 is actually a pretty good Wear OS watch, it really is...however, the haptics are so friggin' anemic I miss 90% of my notification vibrations due to the poor haptic engine it has. (this is an issue with hundreds of thousands of other TicWatch Pro 3 owners...it's on many online threads if you're curious) That isn't the case here with the series 7. I get ALL my notifications and in a timely manner and that on-screen keyboard with swipe-like ability is fantastic. It's not as good as the Google keyboard, but it isn't far behind...and for quick text input, especially if you're in a loud environment where you cannot use voice dictation, or you're in a quiet place or you simply don't want people around you to hear what you're replying, this is a wonderful tool and it works pretty great. Kudos to apple for adding it. I want to mention the haptic engine again...it's actually quite impressive. It vibrates in a totally different manner than ALL other smart watches I've ever owned. It works beautifully and it is hard to miss a notification due to it's efficiency. I swear, if my TicWatch had a decent haptic engine and better music-transfer capability, I may never have even considered getting the apple watch at all.This the only smartwatch besides Samsung to make transferring music to your watch pretty seamless. OR SO I THOUGHT. I tried almost a dozen different programs supposedly designed to help convert my mp3's to easily transfer to my phone and then onto my watch. Almost every one would cap you at transferring 10 songs per day ONLY - unless you paid money. Even iTunes was a problem saying that I had to change this setting on my phone in order to transfer music...yet no matter how often I changed the setting, it still said I needed to do the same thing again. I deleted iTunes and re-downloaded it and tried again. Nope. Same issue. I finally discovered a program called, "SynciOS" which allowed me to transfer music in a pretty intuitive manner and do it ridiculously quick. Not sure why it took so long to be able to do something so simple, but sheesh, this was essentially the only thing that really frustrated me regarding my series 7 watch. Samsung makes this process STUPID EASY to do and sorry apple fans, is FAR SUPERIOR to how apple does it. All other Wear OS watches are no better at making this an easy process and in fact, can make it even more difficult.I love how on my hikes, while listening to music on my watch, I'll get updates every mile I've reached. This is another great feature...but its one that is done better with the Galaxy Watches. The Original GW and the GW3 and GW4 all give you this same information but goes a few steps further. Samsung tells you when you've reached that mile, but also tells you how many steps you've taken to get there AND your heart rate. It only takes 3-4 extra seconds and it works great. The difference between Tizen and Wear OS however is that with TIzen the music would halt while the watch reads out that info thru the bluetooth earbuds, while Wear OS it just slightly lowers the volume of music and tells you the information. Apple lowers the music volume much lower which makes hearing your metrics much easier, but still, the more information the better as far as I'm concerned. Yesterday I wore both my GW3 and the apple watch and they each marked every mile within probably 4-5 seconds of one another - or roughly 15-20 feet difference, which says they both were pretty spot-on for how they measured distance. They both were within about 7 steps of each other as well and heart rate were off by 1 or 2 beats per minute. That tells me either they are both accurate, or both are off by roughly the same amount. There may be a few workout routines that apple doesn't cover which Samsung does and vice versa, but they do all the one's I personally use regularly and that's what counts as far as I'm concerned. Great implementation, too.All in all, you've made this Android user a convert. Though, I still prefer using my Samsung phone. Sorry guys.***UPDATE***Battery life compared to my GW4 is simply astonishing - especially considering how much people whine about it online. Case in point: yesterday I braved the snow and 15 degree temps and walked the 5 miles home from work for my exercise. I wore both my Galaxy Watch 4 and apple watch 7. Keep in mind before I left, I topped off my GW4 til it was at 100%, something I could not do with my apple watch since I do not have a spare charger at work like I do with my Samsung watches, which seem to need it more often. I will stipulate that after a few weeks using my GW4 the battery life improved significantly as it "learned" my habits and adjusted accordingly. I used GPS on both to keep track of my walk, and listened to music downloaded to both watches and switched from one to the other exactly at the half-way point to make it fair. By the time I reached home, my GW4 was down to 61%. Now keep in mind I had been using my apple watch since 5am that morning and wasn't able to charge it before leaving for home. When I hit home my apple watch 7 was still at 79%. That is astonishing to me...and an enormously HUGE difference. I have suspected the battery life was better, but not by THAT much. I just looked it up, and the 45mm apple Watch 7 has a battery size of 309 mAh, while the GW4 has a battery size of 361 mAh. Sorry, but this is a GINORMOUS apple win here. It seems every other review I read about the newest apple watch, one of the chief complaints is battery life, but when compared to the GW4, I cannot help but be happy with it's performance so far. After having used the apple watch for over a week, using the GW4 reminded me (again) that Wear OS just isn't quite there yet. The crazy glitches that plague this system, the incessant notification of voicemail that is NEVER there 100% of the time whenever I turn the watch off and turn it back on again, the notification that my watch is playing media that isn't there, or that it's paired with a kindle that I have never paired it with, the slowness of opening apps and closing them again, the problem of pulling down the settings menu and how it works about half the time I try to pull it down, or scroll up working only part of the time, or how I close all apps only to discover some still open - apps I've never tried to open since the day I bought my watch...the list goes on and on. You know what glitches I've had with the apple watch? NONE. Seriously. I haven't had one single hiccup since I turned this device on. I truly wished this were not the case with my Samsung. The honest truth is I wouldn't even have an apple watch were it not for my sour experience with the newest Galaxy Watch. I still hope that a future update will correct most of these problems, and if so, I will be thrilled to see them implemented and will gladly state so. Problem is, I don't think this is Samsung's problem, it's an issue with Wear OS and Samsung can only do so much to correct it. I DO find it interesting that my older TicWatch Pro 3 has shown far fewer issues and glitches than the GW4 in pretty much every situation...so maybe its a combination of Wear OS and Samsung's version of Wear OS 3.0. Either way, I've been very disappointed in my experience and wish that they had never switched from Tizen in the first place. Oh well. Time will tell if Wear OS can correct these issues or not.The body composition feature is cool on the GW4. I really thought it would be more useful, though. I suppose it can be, but - for me at least - it simply hasn't been something that I've been able to get any kind of genuine use out of. Reportedly it can actually measure your blood pressure...but on a watch? I honestly cannot see how accurate that could be using any kind of method the way the watch is set up. Every reputable medical site I have looked at says the tech is far too new and simply isn't capable - yet anyway - of accurately being able to measure blood pressure monitoring. Kudos to Samsung for initiating it, but at this point, I wouldn't put a whole lot of stock on accuracy.Charging...so, since this is my first apple watch, I can't compare it's supposedly 33% faster charging over previous models...but I WILL say it's faster than the Galaxy Watch 4, 3, Original Galaxy Watch etc. and my TicWatch Pro 3...however, I have an Oppo Watch (which was clearly a ripoff of the apple watch design, but in their defense, they did a STELLAR job with it), now that watch charges FAST. Exactly how much faster, I cannot say for certain, but let's just say all of those other models I mentioned pale in comparison. I just find it absurd that apple did not include a charging block. An utterly imbecilic decision.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2021
title: Android Fanboy Finally Gets An Apple Watch
Color: Blue Aluminum Case with Abyss Blue Sport Band

text: Unpacking is a bit difficult, but not too bad. This is typical for Apple's super fancy packaging. Attaching the watch band is very easy and obvious. Next comes the pairing with your iPhone. This is not so easy or obvious but works quite well as long as you know your iPhone passcode and put the watch on top of your iPhone face down as suggested by the pairing software. Once synced with your iPhone you will be prompted to set a passcode for the watch. Do set it, but not until you have finished the total setup. Your watch now contains a lot of personal information that you should protect. When you take your watch off your wrist, the passcode request comes on very quickly, so if you want to work on your watch with it off your wrist, temporarily turn the passcode off from the settings icon. There are a couple of things you should do immediately in the settings mode. First, is to put all the icons in a list instead of the cute scattering of icons in the default mode. Second, is to swipe up from the bottom and put the watch in theater mode. This makes the watch silent except for haptic vibrations and turns the screen off (hugely increasing battery life, in my case, more than doubling the stated 18 hours). Two taps on the screen turns the screen back on for a short period. You can use your nose to turn on the screen if your other hand is occupied (your chin will not work). I am now sure you can receive and make phone calls in this mode. Holding down the side button will activate Alexa and allow voice commands such as "Call John Smith". After these two, use the U-Tube videos or the online watch manuals to further customize the watch.There are lots of entertainment features built into the watch and into your iPhone and plenty of apps to download if you feel the need.The biggest built-in is health monitoring if you feel the need to know your vitals (heart rate, oxygen levels etc.). Under health monitoring is fall detection. This could save your life and is one of the best reasons to own an Apple watch series 7 whether you are young or old.Why 4-stars instead of 5? It is all about the passcode when the watch is off your wrist. There needs to be a timer on the passcode so that it can be delayed for a few minutes or longer while you work on the watch's settings. As it is right now, you have to manually turn the passcode off while it is on your wrist and then remember to turn it back on in order to work on the settings off of your wrist.I highly recommend purchasing a screen protector, since this fairly large watch can bump into things and scratch the screen. It is much easier to replace a $2 screen protector (clear plastic covering) than it is to repair the screen.There is an interesting small battery-operated recharger for the watch that could be useful if you use the watch a lot while away from home or away from A/C power (in a car or plane) . Lopnord Wireless Charger for Apple Watch. It is so small that it fits in your pocket or purse and can recharge the watch at least one to one and a half times. I've got one and will review it separately and come back to this review when I am confident that it works well. It works very well and can be used by itself or when plugged into a USB port for recharging.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2022
title: Expensive toy with some very useful features

text: As already posted in previous reviews, this watch doesn’t come with the usb c brick that you need to charge it, so buy yourself one when you order your new watch. I already had one because I recently bought an iPhone 13 pro. That and the shorter battery life of this watch are the only drawbacks. You’re going to have to charge this watch every 24 hours. That being said, it’s a wonderful watch. It came in sealed, Apple packaging. The watch box was sealed on both ends. I mention this because of a few other reviews that complain of unsealed packaging and missing items. It has many features and I love that the health app integrates with the watch and you can view all of the data collected by the watch there. I ordered and received the 41mm. I’m a woman and I find that an adequate size for my wrist and I’m actually glad that I didn’t get the 45mm because it would have been too big and I’m not a dainty female with a small wrist. It has a lot of apps available and I took about a third of them off and that made the ones I wanted easier to view. It has a lot of watch faces to choose from and there are watch face apps available as well. I would have preferred a different color but with all of the watch bands available to choose from and different colors of hard screen protectors out there, it really didn’t matter and it’s a great price. I did purchase the offered insurance for $79 as well. All in all, it’s a great watch. The last comment I’d make is that something as basic as a wall charger that’s required to charge the product that you’ve just spent several hundred $$ on, should include it. Are you listening Apple? Probably not, oh well.

text: Hello. I’ve been eying the Series 7 for awhile as I had a Series 5 for a year and a half so I finally upgraded. People that complain about not having a charging brick in the box need to read the description as the description clearly says it doesn’t come with one so why complain about something that you should’ve known from the get go? They should do better research on what they buy next time and plus if you bought a new smart phone or even tablet within the last few years you should have a spare USB C charging brick laying around if not just suck it up and buy one Apple doesn’t include one so it can save on waste and declutters their packaging. The USB C Apple Watch cable allows the Series 7 to charge faster so I rather have a cable that allows me to charge my watch faster just in case if I forget to charge my watch or if I’m having a jam packed day ahead of me and need to charge it as much as I can so I can either get my day started or continue my day.

text: I have given this a lower rating of 2 because of Apple's stupidity. The watch itself is fine and should be rated higher. However, on the 7-series and on the latest iPad's, Apple has changed the charging cord on both ends. Both the insert connector to the power source and the connector to the watch (iPad) are different from previous versions and are not compatible with previous chargers. The power source can no longer be a USB port as the connector doesn't fit. And old charging cords cannot be used as they don't fit the iWatch or the iPad. This means you have to have double sets of chargers around, including automobile charges It is very annoying and irritating. Why did Apple do this?In addition, I unplug the charger from my iPad at my own peril. When I reconnect it it doesn't always start charging. I have to fiddle with the connections on both ends, and even the AC adapter until it starts charging. This makes me leery about removing the charger to take the iPad elsewhere. It is not the cords or AC adapter as two sets do the same thing.Is it just me or do others feel that Apple has gone downhill since Steve Jobs is not longer there.

date: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2021
title: The watch of the year

text: So this is my first fitness tracker / smart watch. In fact its my first watch of any kind for a few years. I tried the cellular version and then returned it a few weeks ago for the GPS only version. Primary goal of the cellular was to free myself from carrying my phone whilst going running. too many subscription based apps, however, made this impractical, so the data plan wasn't really of much use. Plus it chews through more battery (more on that later). So yeah I think the tech ability  is finally here but Apple's ecosystem isn't very friendly to bundling your own playlists, so I continue to run with my phone AND watch AND bt headphones. Boo. Friggin. Who.I am guessing the white band of the Starlight model probably turns a lot of people off, but you should know that bands are really easy to change, and cheap on the after market. I love the look of the starlight watch frame with a colored band. it gives the watch both the ability to be uniquely fun but can also have a more conservative look with a gun metal grey band.The touch features are fantastic, as are the health features like vital signs. I've compared them to a real pulse oximeter and the o2 readouts are within 1% every time. Even the EKG sinus rhythm appears quite similar to a 12 lead. Remember, though, that this feature will not reliably detect (rule out) a heart attack.Usability is quite good, also. the mini keyboard is surprisingly easy to use. Sure its not your phone, but it gets the job done. Voice to text is great and I find myself using that more than the keyboard. After about a week it primarily becomes just a time piece on your wrist as the novelty wears off, but appreciable features include the ability to glance at texts without pulling out my phone, and the flashlight feature is very handy as well.there are a number of plastic/rubber covers on the market. I bought a two pack for use when i'll be out in the yard or an area where the watch may see more abuse. its more difficult to apply than changing the bands, which must come off to apply a protective cover. The screen naturally looses a small degree of touch sensitivity but is still quite usable. Mostly I go about my business without the cover. the 7 purportedly has a more durable screen and in a few months of use now I've yet to scratch it.My biggest complaint, other than the music options for going running, is the battery life. I find myself charging it two or three times a day. Not that it needs that many top offs, but I don't like seeing any battery dip below 50%. the nice thing is that the charge is quite quick and painless with the so-called hockey puck. I can't imagine how frustrated I'd be with previous generations that don't charge as quickly as the 7.if you have small wrists go for the 41mm. Medium and large will probably be happier with the 45mm.

title: Good, not great.

text: I do a lot of research before making large purchases and I surely did before deciding on the Apple Watch 7.  I was considering the Apple Watch SE mostly for price.  I was upgrading from a Series 3 so anything would be better.  After reading details and specs I landed on the Series 7 45mm with cellular.  I've worn it everyday for the past 2 weeks and I know I made the right decision.  The watch face is large and clear.  I can easily use apps and respond to text message.  I realized I actually use my phone less while out and about.I can highly recommend the Series 7 to anyone who has a older series watch or has never purchased one before.  If you have a 5 or 6, I would wait to see what the NEW Series 8 has to offer, unless you just want a bigger screen.I also recommend to read the information concerning your watch choice before buying.  Many people do not do their (homework) before buying, then complain about the product.  Apple no longer supplies the charging block with their iPhones, Watches or AirPods.  The 11pro, 12 series, 13 series iPhones have USB-C to Lightning cables.  The Watch Series 7 also uses this cable.  Meaning, if you don't have access to USB-C charging you will need to purchase a charging block.  I can recommend Apple or Anker products.  Also, the Apple Watch Series 7 requires your iPhone to be updated to the latest iOS version.  Interestedly enough, all this is noted on the outside of the box your watch comes in, as well as on the documentation in the box.I hope this helps you in making a decision concerning the Apple Watch Series 7.  So many of the reviews I read through were a joke, fake or just a idiot user.  Cheers

title: Fantastic Watch!

text: I expected the latest watch to work seamlessly with the latest iPhone.  This is the latest watch.  I have the latest iPhone.I'm in recovery from two episodes of a dangerous heart arrhythmia and my exercise program consists of approximately 1 hour moderately intense walks each day.  At minimum, I wanted the watch to count steps, maybe measure distance as well, and measure and keep track of my heart rate.  I also expected to be able to access this information fairly easily and when I wanted to on my iPhone as well as on the watch.Apple buried the pedometer if it has one, and if it has one, you can't put it on the watch face I just spent a long time selecting as the one that I liked.  Apparently Apple restricts third parties from creating useful watch faces, so there aren't that many, and there isn't one I could put what I wanted on.I installed a pedometer app.  I bought the watch having been assured by the salesman that this watch had or this watch even was a pedometer.  What am I doing installing a pedometer app?  This seemed like buying an iPhone and having to install a phone app.  If you know the watch OS, I hope it wouldn't take you that long to set this up just the way you want it, but I didn't have the patience.  I think I got the number of steps to display but then there wasn't a place to put the heart rate.  I expected less hassle for this simple function.I opened the iPhone Watch app.  I'm sure there is a way to get it out of the Settings screen, but at this point, as I was about to refresh my perception of how this app wasn't that easy to use, I can't get it to do anything except alter various settings.  I can't back out of the Settings into the program itself.  I've only been using computers since 1982 or so, when I studied assembly language on a machine with 1K Ram and cassette tape instead of a hard drive, so it could be that I'm not capable of figuring out how to operate the easy to use Apple software interface.I even have an Apple Watch for Dummies book, the latest edition.  I ended up looking online for solutions to problems as they came up because for me the book was full of a lot of tips and info except no info on the particular problem, whatever it was, that I had.Apple doesn't even consider the type of exercise that I am doing at the moment, i.e. fairly gentle walking coming back from a serious heart issue, as exercise.  So they program their software out of the box to ignore the type of walking I do, so people say.  Maybe the watch can be tweaked or if I muttered the right incantation it might decide my walks are exercise,  but as I looked for info on how to make the watch display information about my proposed walks, the first warnings I ran into were that walks are not exercise in the Apple ecosystem unless they are of a certain intensity.  I don't know because I couldn't set up the watch well enough to even take it for a walk before I gave up and told my wife, who gave it to me as a present, that I was going to send it back.The screen is beautiful.  The 45mm watch seems too big and bulky for me and I am 6 foot 1 inch with big hands.  The aesthetically appealing watch faces are the least customizable.  I made sure to turn the alarm off but it went off at 6:30 am anyway, and it would not manually stop sounding off every few minutes after that.  Etc.  I'm sure I could have found some setting other than alarm OFF that would have made the alarm not be set to go off tomorrow morning, but...

text: So I’m only writing to say I have no idea what’s with some of these reviews. Okay no IT doesn’t come with a 9.99 block to usb-c. Big deal. If you can spend $400 bucks on a watch I think we can get that piece. It DOES come with the magnetic charger super fast charge chord that is $30 bucks. Also this watch syncs perfectly fine. I’ve bought 3 so far. For people that claim to be tech savvy but took 6 hours? I’m pretty with it still but other than saying did I want to sync it to my phone AFTER updating the phone it was fine. You buy a tech wifi product and it’s going to need updates but other than it telling and showing you how to sync up your phone there’s literally nothing to this. I bought it for my 82 year old mother . Showed her in minutes how to take an ECG, and pulse ox. Send a message, make a call, talk to Siri, set an appointment , reminder, alarm, Use the calendar , Set and measure her activity and set her ICE so if she falls and doesn’t get up the phone will contact us. For what it is and all it’s features , ease of use, this thing is amazing. I bought it on the $349. Price which really is pretty remarkable for all of it’s features. Lot’s of complaining here for something that’s a pretty amazing and bonus with an emergency alert for her to get help. I’m not sure how much people feel is okay to pay for all of this but for me it’s one of my favorite things and seeing my moms face light up and marvel over this thing makes me say it’s money well spent. Apple is a business, so is Verizon, Cable companies , service providers any many other monthly expenses that overcharge and don’t include all the accessories you need either. Apps are also money makers but some of them make our lives convenient. Go on you tube and look up how to set up your phones/watches. It shouldn’t take anyone 6 hours. From the time my mom opened it, while on a FaceTime call with my brother in Germany within literally 5 minutes it was syncing to her phone. Nothing difficult about it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2022
title: What’s with some of these Reviews?
Color: Starlight Aluminum Case with Starlight Sport Band

text: The iOS is horrible, frustrating, and counter intuitive. Want a stopwatch? Not on this device! Oh it has a stopwatch that is useless garbage. After one minute, the only thing it displays is 1:—:—. What genius thought of this? It’s not saving battery, the display is still on! You can raise your wrist and the numbers appear, but if I have a heavy dumbbell in my hand or I’m stabilizing it in my lap, I can’t move my wrist. Just have the flipping numbers on screen!! FFS. Do you want to know what minute you’re on after 70 seconds? Tough sh**, the screen switches to the time. So now you’re forced to bring up your wrist. And yes, I’ve looked up and changed every setting possible. Nothing I do prevents this. Well, why don’t you download a third part app? Hey, let’s try that. That was a massive headache itself and after I finally did download a third party stopwatch app that showed all of the numbers, the amazing, intuitive Apple iOS darkens and reverts to the time. Un-flipping-believable. Want to turn that setting off? Tough sh**, Mr. Customer, you can only look at the app for 70 seconds, so screw your three minute timer, peasant. “What you need to do is toggle the hide sensitive complications options on or off.” Guess what, that doesn’t work. Not after 70 seconds. While I’m talking about the display, sometimes an app view screen shows up randomly and I literally can’t do anything to get out of it. The only option I have is to turn it off and back on again. That’s extremely frustrating. Also, they need to figure out which direction the scroll when is used for. One screen the scroll wheel moves the screen in the direction you push the wheel (up is up and down is down), but when you go to move the cursor to edit text, down on the wheel moves the cursor up. Why? Why would they do this? Well we’re on the subject of text, the talk to text on this watch is atrocious. I can say the exact same thing on my iPhone and it works great. The watch simply does a turd job at understanding talk to text. When I do scroll down to go up and select a word to change it to something that I actually said instead of what it wrote, the options simply aren’t there. Ever. Also, when I’m on the workout app tracking my heart rate and I switch to a Stopwatch app to track my time in between sets, I looked down at my watch to check the time and it switched back to the workout app! That’s so extremely frustrating. When I switch to another app I want to look at that flipping app. I don’t want you to change to the time, I don’t want you to change apps regardless of what you think I want to see. It’s little stuff like this that makes me want to ask, will it blend? Sometimes I think putting it down the garbage disposal or in a Vitamix would make me much happier due to the frustration I have with the iOS. What stops me from doing that? The hardware. The hardware is really amazing. I love the way it feels in my wrist, I love the heart rate monitor which never drops my heart rate (unlike every Fitbit or Mio watch I’ve had). The screen is fantastic, the haptics are really nice and not overbearing. For the amount that this thing cost the fact that the software is so crippling there’s no way I can recommend someone purchase this until they get the iOS fixed.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2021

text: I don't understand why people - even real techies are complaining about the charging situation of the watch.  Can't you read?  Need to do your due diligence before buying.  It says what's in the box.  You can buy an Apple 20W charging block for $20.00.  I guarantee you'll need it for the future.  You can also buy adapters.  If you just read what's in the box, you could have avoided lots of stress.  Everything would have arrived together.  As to the updates, from what I understand the updates need go in sequence.  If you don't have the latest, you need to update.  If you don't have one or 2 previous updates you need to add those updates first.  I am an old dog who hates to learn new tricks, Apple make things easier and I'm happier for it.  Thanks Apple

text: I speak for many in the track and field world who have tried and tried to enjoy Apple Watch as a fitness device. Problem is the lack of a physical start/stop button makes timing short races impossible. Whether you are timing yourself on repeat 400s or timing other athletes on 100s, 200s, 800s or miles. Fact is we sweat a lot on the track especially during summer workouts. We need a start and stop button!! Apple clearly hasn’t asked a track athlete’s opinion on this. The Watch is a great device for daily life. However it shouldn’t advertise as a fitness device. If stoping the clock during a summer workout is not possible this it is not a fitness device.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2021
title: Not for Track Athletes

text: I had the series 3 for three years, and never scratched the screen — I use the watch daily and have a very active lifestyle. The series 7, within two weeks, I noticed a huge scratch on it and did not have any incidents where I would have scratched it like this. I googled this problem and discovered many people are experiencing the same thing. Apparently while it's more shatter resistant, it's less scratch resistant. Wish I knew. Definitely get a screen protector, I'm extremely disappointed to have such a gouge in a VERY expensive watch.

text: Amazing - I received this watch as a gift.  Turns out the charging cable is faulty.  Chatted with them online, they told me to go to an apple store who confirmed the cable was faulty after a long examination.  They didn't have any of the new usb-c charging cables and at first said they couldn't send one to me, that I had to come back to the store.  After pressing them, I was told that apple care would call me that night which they did.  They would send one to me as long as I sent the faulty cable back.  9 days later, it hasn't shipped and support continues to fumble around for a response.  They could send me an older model cable...they could send me a new dual mag cable...but no, they continue without a clue.  So much for a premium product and excellent support.  I'm sure the cable costs them <$1.  What's my time and frustration worth?  What's a bad review worth??
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2022

text: My Apple Watch series 7 was a great investment because I use it multiple times every day: day of the month for writing checks, set timer for cooking, outside temperature, outside weather, battery charge, DJIA, tracking sleep. The quarter hour chimes keep my on track throughout the day and serve as a good antidote to procrastination.  The Infographics watch face allows instant monitoring of up to 7 functions ("complications") simultaneously.  For me, one device on my wrist is more convenient than multiple devices in various locations:  in my pocket, on my wall, and on my desk.

title: One device on my wrist replaces multiple devices scattered thru the house.

text: Ordering and receiving went fine. I want to have my step count on the face and I want to see my current heart rate not what it was 7 minutes ago. Those two things make me think my purchase was wrong and I should have stayed with Fitbit. My two other major disappointments are with the battery life ( my Fitbit had a 5-7 day battery life) and not coming with the brick. I had already upgraded my phone so I knew there wouldn’t be a charging brick and cable but still very disappointed. text: I received this watch yesterday. I may rewrite or add to this review later. Day one didn’t go well. The first problem encountered was software update. That took over 30 minutes and then I had to put the watch on the charger to finish updating. An hour later, I began setting up the watch. Each click screen (Accept - do later), the watch froze up. Two hours after starting, the watch finally works, almost. The cellular phone feature didn’t work until 24 hours later. I placed the watch on charge again at 8:00 pm that night. I put the watch back on at 10:30 pm to go to bed with 100% charge. I use the watch as an alarm clock. I was awakened at 7:30 am. The watch showed 79 % charged. So far I have had to charge the watch twice a day. The watch comes with two small bands and no charger.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2021
