text: I suppose it's been a long time coming. I was an early adopter of smart watches having purchased the original Moto 360 (the flat tire, anyone remember that?) along with a string of other Android Wear watches (now Wear OS) from LG, Fossil, Skagen, Mobvoi and eventually going with Samsung's Tizen watches for one simple reason: the OS just worked reliably, especially compared with Android/Wear OS. I got the Gear S2, the S3, Gear Sport, Galaxy Watch and the follow-up, Galaxy Watch 3 (they skipped 2). Then I heard that Samsung was abandoning Tizen and going back to Wear OS - but only after stepping in and helping Google with a software face lift (which it desperately needed) giving us Wear OS 3.0. My first reaction was one of anger and disappointment. I've invested SO MUCH into Tizen and here they go abandoning it?? Slowly, I began to become hopeful that maybe, just MAYBE this was the iteration of Wear OS that fixes the lagging, glitching and stuttering issues that had plagued every single Wear OS device I had ever owned. I WILL say that I have experienced almost no issues with my TicWatch Pro 3 (aside from the utterly abysmal haptic vibration). It is as close to running flawlessly as I have ever experienced with Wear OS. I only assumed that since the Galaxy Watch 4 was about a year NEWER, that it simply HAD to be better, right?It wasn't. The GW4 was as bad as any previous Wear OS watch I had ever used, and in several cases, considerably worse. I was just crestfallen...not to mention, out several hundred dollars having purchased one shortly after release. At first maybe I thought I just had a bad model, but nope. Look online and you'll see my experience isn't isolated in the slightest. It's fairly typical...meaning it's a software issue that Google and Samsung either can't, or won't fix. I preferred my previous Tizen smart watches. A LOT.During all this time however, I had secretly always liked the apple watches. It took a bit to warm up to the square-ish design however, but I finally did. But, that's a far cry from actually wanting to BUY one. Shortly after the release of the Series 7 watch, I discovered something that took me by surprise. Apple now will allow you to use one of their watches WITHOUT needing to have it tethered to an iPhone. This caught my attention BIG TIME. Initially I wanted to set one up without an iPhone altogether because no matter how fast or efficient iOS is, I will never like it as much as I do the customization you get with Android that apple simply CANNOT touch no matter how hard they try.The truth is, you MUST have an iPhone to set up your watch initially...THEN you can operate it without needing an iPhone. Thankfully I was able to get both thru my job. I now have an iPhone 12 and a blue, 45mm Apple Watch 7 LTE. I prefer my watch. Like, A LOT. Am I ready to say it's altogether better than my Galaxy Watch 4? Oh, absolutely without question. There are a few things I preferred with my GW4 though, such as the ease of adding music to the watch for listening to while working out. Seriously, NOBODY makes adding music to their smart watch easier. I initially thought it was going to be a breeze, but boy was I mistaken. It took 3 days before I found a program that would allow me to transfer my music (in bulk, several other programs let you do it, but unless you paid a fee, they would only allow you to do 10 songs per day - and let's face it, I don't have the patience to download 300 songs over the course of 30 days. I finally discovered a program that made the transfer relatively simple, but honestly, apple shouldn't make you work THAT hard to do this one thing IMO. HUGE pain in my behind in order to get this done, but now that I have......I love my Series 7 watch. It looks great, like really. That screen is fantastic. Not any better than my Samsung watches, but easily as good. I DO think it can get a wee bit brighter, though. I've read a few people saying setting up their Series 7 took forever while claiming to be tech-oriented...but that wasn't my experience at all. Seriously, coming to iOS BRAND NEW, and barely understanding how an iPhone works compared with Android, I was able to set up my watch and had it on my wrist within 15-20 minutes or so. Easy peasy. Yes, I consider myself fairly good at operating new tech, but some of these other experiences I've read about simply seems foreign to me after the smooth experience I had. I will say this however, since my watch was ordered online and shipped to me, I didn't really inspect whether or not the cellular function was actually working until I had been using the watch for a good 2 weeks or so. It wasn't set up, and in fact, took a bit to finally hammer out how to do it, and I finally figured it out, but if I'm honest, I was on the last step of what I was going to try before bringing it into a store to have the experienced folks at T-Mobile do it for me. Yes, it was unnecessarily complicated and shouldn't be. Oh well, I thought I'd include that anyway.So overall, what do I think about my Apple Watch 7? It runs as flawlessly as I had hoped - and not just a little better than the Samsung Galaxy Watch 4...it can runs CIRCLES around that watch. I would say my older Galaxy Watch 3 runs as smooth as the Series 7 does though. It may not be quite as fast overall, but I have never had an issue with my Tizen watches glitching or stuttering, at least so far anyway. The watch sync's up with my iPhone 12 seamlessly - which really IS one of the hallmarks of apple products being able to link together so well and kudos to Cupertino for doing that job so well. My Tizen and Wear OS watches will have issues connecting with my phones about 30% of the time which is annoying. This was a bigger issue with my Tizen watches than any of the Wear OS devices, so I'm not sure what the issue is, but it was definitely one I spotted right away.Honestly, the truth of the matter is this: I just want my watch to work reliably when I need it to. I just cannot say that about pretty much every Wear OS watch I've owned. When I turn my watch on, I almost forget about it because I don't have to worry about it not connecting to my phone, or sending me notifications, it just WORKS.Haptics are just better on apple than any other smart watch made - at least any that I am currently familiar with. It's hard to describe the difference. The watch vibrates differently than every other I've ever owned and it's very, VERY hard to miss. Great job, apple.I don't think there are as many watch faces that are truly as good as the variety I had with TIzen, but I like a lot of them, and for that I'm happy.I really like the digital crown for navigating the watch, especially when I don't want to touch the screen. Very cool. I still think Samsung's circular bezel is hands-down the best way to navigate without touching the face, but this is as close as you can get I believe and it works great.I love the health benefits of using the watch, too. Keeping track of my workouts is great. I have worn my GW3 and my apple watch a couple times and noticed they were virtually identical in readings, so I'd say they both record workouts fairly well (I did the same with my GW4 as well and found it on par, too). There are some things I prefer with one OS over the other, like after I've ran a mile, I preferred the way Tizen stops the music entirely to tell you that you've reached 1 mile, how long it took you, how many steps and your current heart rate and then re-starts the music. Wear OS 3.0 is slightly different. It doesn't stop the music, just lowers the volume while it tells you much the same info but slightly different. The apple watch just tells you that you've completed a mile and how long it took while the music audio lowers in volume. I'm not sure if you can have it read back more info or not, but if there is, I haven't found it. All things considered, I prefer the Galaxy Watch 3 way of telling you info to the rest...but this is purely subjective. The active rings though...? I'm not sure I care about them to be honest, but for those who do, they can be helpful.I love the ability to answer texts using that keyboard instead of having to use the Siri/microphone (which is WAY better than Bixby, let's be clear on that). It works surprisingly well with the swype feature enabled. I'm very happy about that. You can also use scribble if you'd rather write it out letter by letter with your finger. I don't usually use this, but always nice to have as an option.So...how is battery life? Well, after doing a lot of research on the apple watches over the years and especially leading up to my getting one, I have been absolutely floored by how good it has been. Seriously, I expected it to suck right out of the box. But - it didn't. The best battery life I've ever experienced still goes to the Mobvoi TicWatch Pro 3 (and yes, I realize the battery it has is much bigger, but still) followed by my original Galaxy Watch. The GW3 and 4 have each gotten steadily worse battery life than those other 2...and this is another gripe I have with Wear OS (despite the fact the TicWatch runs that same OS)...most manufacturers either forego giving us a bigger battery, or just have us deal with crappy battery life and rarely do we get much in the way of anything in the middle...unless you're comparing those with the apple watch. I was VERY surprised at how good it's been. To compare, twice I have walked 5 miles home from work, wearing both my Galaxy Watch 3 and the apple watch, and the GW4 and the apple watch. I used GPS and bluetooth for music listening and when I got home, the apple watch had more juice...by as much as 15-20% more. For those who are familiar with smart watches, if you kick in the GPS its going to adversely affect your battery life significantly. Same with listening to music. I never use the always on display, so that isn't a factor at all for me. The GW3 has had better battery life than the 4 from the very beginning (and the original GW had even better battery life), but the apple watch routinely still has 70-80% full battery when I get home, depending on how far I've walked and how much I've used it to check on incoming texts, emails etc. With the GW3 I'm usually have 60% or so and the GW4 is below 50%, sometimes down to almost 40% by the same point in my hiking and after the same amount of time being on my wrist since I woke up. I don't really bother with sleep tracking or trying to squeeze another day out of the battery life, so that doesn't intrigue me. I tend to put the watch on the charger at the end of every day no matter where its at and shut it off once it's been topped off. But based on what I have at the end of each day, I'm fairly confident I could get 2 days use, and especially if I didn't use it for GPS and bluetooth listening...but I haven't actually tried to do that, so I'm not 100% certain of this. All I know is for MY practical experience, I've been very happy with the battery life. Don't get me wrong, I'd love twice the battery life I'm already getting, but I think you get the idea.I love the customization of the watch bands...but in this day, if you release a watch that cannot support being able to swap out different watch bands, you deserve to fail. I have the blue 45mm variant watch and I think it looks fantastic. That screen is 20% larger than the Series 6 they say, and while I've not used an apple watch before, the watch itself doesn't really look bigger and the more screen you can use isn't super obvious unless you have an older model literally right next to it to compare it with. For those who are using an even older watch, you probably will notice the difference, especially if you've been using the Series 3.I recommend watching some YouTube videos that teach you the best way to utilize your watch, get the most out of it, best apps to download and how to maximize battery life if you truly want to squeeze every drop of power from your watch you can. They are very helpful.If only they would allow you to use an apple watch with an android, WOW I may never go back to a Wear OS device ever again...and as long as I'm admitting things, as it stands right now, I doubt I will be buying any other brand of smart watch in the future now that I've used the Series 7 and have seen what a truly capable smart watch can do regularly that doesn't include glitches, stuttering and whatnot. Just keepin' it real, y'all. In short, I love my watch. Kudos to apple for producing a watch that truly does earn the title of best smart watch available. I just wish Samsung would go back to Tizen. But oh well. So many believe it was a smart move to go back to Wear OS, but I'm sorry folks, I'm not one of them. At least not with the current way their watches perform. HUGE let down IMO.***UPDATE***I have to say something about Siri and it's ability to write text for you. It is ridiculously fast. Easily on par with Google Assistant, and a bit faster than any Wear OS device I have personally ever used. It is remarkably accurate, too. SUPER Kudos for that. Also, the included keyboard is pretty sweet. It isn't quite as easy to use as the GBoard for Wear OS, but it is definitely better than all the other included keyboards I've seen for smart watches (again, other than GBoard). Another mark in apple's favor IMO.I wish I knew why apple chose to turn on the watches WiFi every single time you enter a building and your phone attempts to hook up to it. I wish there was a way to disable this automatic feature and so far, haven't been able to figure it out...I don't think I can at this point.I love the complications you can add to your screen. VERY customizable. Better implemented than Wear OS or Tizen watches I have to say. Most faces can add a lot - but not all apps as complications if you choose to. Some limit you to only a couple, but hey, at least there's the option, right? I prefer one for each corner of the screen. Some faces allow for even more than that. Again, very well done and very convenient!***UPDATE #2***I want to say I really appreciate how fast the charging is. I also want to say that by now, apple really is behind the ball when it comes to reverse wireless charging of their watches. C'mon guys, are you just lazy? Same with Samsung not including at least fastER charging by this point. Seriously, both have screwed the public when it comes to this one area. My series 7 charges quite a bit faster than my GW4, but I can also top off my GW4 using my Galaxy S21 Ultra anywhere I'm at...both have good and bad points here folks. It's up to you to decide which is best for your own personal uses though. I'm just pointing them out is all.***UPDATE #3***I discovered a couple things. The main reason why the battery is so good when I'm on my hikes while it's using GPS and bluetooth to play music is because it's actually using the GPS thru my phone. When I went on a walk the other day and left my iPhone at home, I came back and noticed an astonishingly big discrepancy of battery usage from when my phone is with me. From 92% after a 5 mile hike to 63% for the same walk without my phone. Hmmm. Interesting. Also, adding music STILL SUCKS. I've added songs I don't know HOW many times that still don't show up on my watch. So friggin' frustrating. This is one area Samsung not only wins, but literally decimates apple in simplicity and ease of use. Trust me, that's a feat considering how buggy my Galaxy Watch 4 is.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2022
title: Admitted Android Fanboy LOVES My Apple Watch 7
Color: Blue Aluminum Case with Abyss Blue Sport Band

I was banging on the counter top the other night (after grinding coffee beans) and the watch wanted to know if I had taken a hard fall.  The phone portion of the watch sounds great on both ends and the step count is fairly accurate.  I'm still way behind on just what this watch can do, but so far, it's been really amazing.  Highly recommended!!

text: Had this watch for maybe three weeks now? So far it works great, I love the sleep tracking and the ecg apps. I’m a telemetry tech so I find it neat to see my own rhythm and not have to put on the hospitals box to see it 😂The battery lasts roughly 24 hours depending how much I’m on it (which is a lot because I’m still toying will all it has to offer). Love that I can locate my phone with my watch and vice versa (yes, I lose my phone a lot in my own home). I didn’t realize I could actually take calls on the watch, that was pretty cool the first time I answered, and it was clear. Love that instead of looking down at my phone while using gps, it’s right on my wrist where to turn. Overall my switch from android in general has been pretty successful so far. Just wished I didn’t have to charge the watch every day while my phone lasts 2-3 (sometimes 4) days. I just charge it while I’m folding laundry and it takes roughly an hour to reach 100%, so I will take that fast charge any day!
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2022
title: So far I love it!

text: o produto veio em estado impecável e chegou 2 semanas antes do previsto. sobre o relógio em si, ele é muito prático e me ajuda muito a controlar questões de saúde, como por exemplo, os "anéis" diários, em que você estabelece uma meta de horas em pé, exercício e queima de caloria, e quando você completa essas 3 metas, você recebe alguns prêmios e isso me motiva bastante. ele também acompanha 3 meses gratuitos do fitness+, aplicativo de exercícios da própria apple. as telas iniciais do apple watch 7, em minha opinião, são maravilhosas também. a bateria não dura tanto, geralmente dura 1 dia e meio pra mim, mas a recarga é absurdamente rápida - você consegue ir de 5% à 90% em 30 minutos. um lado negativo é que vem sem a fonte do carregador, que é diferente da fonte normal, mas não é muito difícil encontrar na internet. no geral, o produto vale muito a pena pela funcionalidade e praticidade, além da integração do sistema apple que é simplesmente maravilhosa!
